dc.contributor.author: Chen, Xihan||Andersen, Thorbjørn J.||Morono, Yuki||Inagaki, Fumio||Jørgensen, Bo B.||Lever, Mark A.
dc.description.abstract: The factors controlling the relative abundances of Archaea and Bacteria in marine sediments are poorly understood. We determined depth distributions of archaeal and bacterial 16S rRNA genes by quantitative PCR at eight stations in Aarhus Bay, Denmark. Bacterial outnumber archaeal genes 10–60-fold in uppermost sediments that are irrigated and mixed by macrofauna. This bioturbation is indicated by visual observations of sediment color and faunal tracks, by porewater profiles of dissolved inorganic carbon and sulfate, and by distributions of unsupported 210Pb and 137Cs. Below the depth of bioturbation, the relative abundances of archaeal genes increase, accounting for one third of 16S rRNA genes in the sulfate zone, and half of 16S rRNA genes in the sulfate-methane transition zone and methane zone. Phylogenetic analyses reveal a strong shift in bacterial and archaeal community structure from bioturbated sediments to underlying layers. Stable isotopic analyses on organic matter and porewater geochemical gradients suggest that macrofauna mediate bacterial dominance and affect microbial community structure in bioturbated sediment by introducing fresh organic matter and high-energy electron acceptors from overlying seawater. Below the zone of bioturbation, organic matter content and the presence of sulfate exert key influences on bacterial and archaeal abundances and overall microbial community structure.
dc.title: Bioturbation as a key driver behind the dominance of Bacteria over Archaea in near-surface sediment

dc.contributor.author: Steinsberger, Thomas
dc.description.abstract: The flux of reduced substances (Fred), the oxygen consumption by the mineralization of freshly settled organic matter (sediment oxygen uptake, SOU) and the mineralization of organic matter within the water column (WCM) are the main factors that contribute to the depletion of oxygen in the hypolimnion of lakes. The relative importance of each process and its limiting or driving factors are still debated as freshwater management remains a crucial topic. This study focuses on the origin and scale of Fred and SOU in the hypolimnion of various lakes. Identifying a common driving factor for Fred and SOU generation has been a major goal of lake oxygen research in the past. So far, observations of Fred and SOU are mostly based on single measurements in selected lakes and could not claim broader implications for lake systems. However, a detailed understanding of the underlying processes is essential for managing the oxygen depletion in the hypolimnion of lakes.  In this study, we present a large dataset of porewater concentrations and the corresponding fluxes of reduced substances combined with state of the art oxygen microsensor measurements in order to improve the understanding of oxygen consumption in the hypolimnion of lakes. Measurements were performed in a wide range of different lake types to include as many different lake systems as possible: in the eutrophic artificially aerated Lake Baldegg, in the mesotrophic Lake Hallwil currently recovering from eutrophication, in the oligotrophic Lake Aegeri, in the eutrophic but meromictic Lake Zug, and in the meso-eutrophic Lake Geneva. During two extensive field campaigns in 2013 and 2014, we collected and analyzed over 130 sediment cores and recorded almost 100 O2 profiles at the sediment-water interface.  This study shows that porewater fluxes of reduced substances developed great spatial variations in case sediment and/or geochemical focusing was active, while Fred was more homogenous in lakes without these processes. Clear seasonal patterns of Fred were not evident, although pursuable indications existed. The total organic carbon mass accumulation rate (TOC-MAR) was found to be the main driving factor for Fred generation. TOC-MAR was not merely related to the trophic state of a lake but was enhanced due to sediment focusing, high terrestrial input or low hypolimnetic oxygen concentration while it was decreased by prevailing high hypolimnetic oxygen concentrations. Likewise, Fred was linked to the mean hypolimnion depth, a proxy for the size of the hypolimnetic oxygen inventory of a lake, as this largely determined the availability of oxygen in the hypolimnion regulating the degradation of OC. Both relationships, Fred with TOC-MAR and Fred with the mean hypolimnion depth, offer an opportunity to estimate Fred based on more readily available data sets. In very deep lakes with a large hypolimnion volume like Lake Geneva, Fred was negligible for the areal hypolimnetic mineralization rate (AHM). In Lake Geneva, oxygen fluxes estimated from concentration profiles (SOU) recorded simultaneously with the determination of Fred were too small to explain the high AHM estimated from monthly water column profiles. Using a simple model, we postulated that the mineralization of OC within the water column of Lake Geneva was the main sink for oxygen in the hypolimnion. In summary, this study demonstrated the value of in-situ oxygen measurements linked to simultaneous porewater flux measurements and bulk chemical sediment analysis for testing hypotheses on hypolimnetic oxygen consumption. TOC accumulation rates and prevailing hypolimnetic oxygen concentrations determine the flux of reduced substances from lake sediments. In very deep lakes, Fred and SOU are not able to fully explain AHM and hence hint to another oxygen sink which is hypothesized to be the mineralization of OC within the large water column. In addition, the study presents simple parameterizations for estimating Fred and SOU for lakes where direct measurements are not available.

dc.title: Hypolimnetic oxygen consumption in deep Swiss lakes

dc.contributor.author: Nikolic, Nela||Schreiber, Frank||Dal Co, Alma||Kiviet, Daniel J.||Bergmiller, Tobias||Littmann, Sten||Kuypers, Marcel M.M.||Ackermann, Martin
dc.description.abstract: While we have good understanding of bacterial metabolism at the population level, we know little about the metabolic behavior of individual cells: do single cells in clonal populations sometimes specialize on different metabolic pathways? Such metabolic specialization could be driven by stochastic gene expression and could provide individual cells with growth benefits of specialization. We measured the degree of phenotypic specialization in two parallel metabolic pathways, the assimilation of glucose and arabinose. We grew Escherichia coli in chemostats, and used isotope-labeled sugars in combination with nanometer-scale secondary ion mass spectrometry and mathematical modeling to quantify sugar assimilation at the single-cell level. We found large variation in metabolic activities between single cells, both in absolute assimilation and in the degree to which individual cells specialize in the assimilation of different sugars. Analysis of transcriptional reporters indicated that this variation was at least partially based on cell-to-cell variation in gene expression. Metabolic differences between cells in clonal populations could potentially reduce metabolic incompatibilities between different pathways, and increase the rate at which parallel reactions can be performed.
dc.title: Cell-to-cell variation and specialization in sugar metabolism in clonal bacterial populations

dc.contributor.author: Oney, Brian||Gruber, Nicolas||Henne, Stephan||Leuenberger, Markus||Brunner, Dominik
dc.description.abstract: Regional-scale inverse modeling of atmospheric carbon dioxide (CO2) holds promise to determine the net CO2 fluxes between the land biosphere and the atmosphere. This approach requires not only high fidelity of atmospheric transport and mixing, but also an accurate estimation of the contribution of the anthropogenic and background CO2 signals to isolate the biospheric CO2 signal from the atmospheric CO2 variations. Thus, uncertainties in any of these three components directly impact the quality of the biospheric flux inversion. Here, we present and evaluate a carbon monoxide (CO)-based method to reduce these uncertainties solely on the basis of co-located observations. To this end, we use simultaneous observations of CO2 and CO from a background observation site to determine the background mole fractions for both gases, and the regional anthropogenic component of CO together with an estimate of the anthropogenic CO/CO2 mole fraction ratio to determine the anthropogenic CO2 component. We apply this method to two sites of the CarboCount CH observation network on the Swiss Plateau, Beromünster and Lägern-Hochwacht, and use the high-altitude site Jungfraujoch as background for the year 2013. Since such a background site is not always available, we also explore the possibility to use observations from the sites themselves to derive the background. We contrast the method with the standard approach of isolating the biospheric CO2 component by subtracting the anthropogenic and background components simulated by an atmospheric transport model. These tests reveal superior results from the observation-based method with retrieved wintertime biospheric signals being small and having little variance. Both observation- and model-based methods have difficulty to explain observations from late-winter and springtime pollution events in 2013, when anomalously cold temperatures and northeasterly winds tended to bring highly CO-enriched air masses to Switzerland. The uncertainty of anthropogenic CO/CO2 emission ratios is currently the most important factor limiting the method. Further, our results highlight that care needs to be taken when the background component is determined from the site’s observations. Nonetheless, we find that future atmospheric carbon monitoring efforts would profit greatly from at least measuring CO alongside CO2.
dc.subject: anthropogenic emissions||model-data fusion||measurement||limited-area atmospheric modeling||inverse modeling||climate change||atmospheric carbon||terrestrial biosphere
dc.title: A CO-based method to determine the regional biospheric signal in atmospheric CO2

dc.contributor.author: Zhong, Qingxia||Carratalà, Anna||Ossola, Rachele||Bachmann, Virginie||Kohn, Tamar
dc.description.abstract: The emergence of waterborne viruses with resistance to disinfection has been demonstrated in the laboratory and in the environment. Yet, the implications of such resistance for virus control remain obscure. In this study we investigate if viruses with resistance to a given disinfection method exhibit cross-resistance to other disinfectants. Chlorine dioxide (ClO2)- or UV-resistant populations of echovirus 11 were exposed to five inactivating treatments (free chlorine, ClO2, UV radiation, sunlight, and heat), and the extent of cross-resistance was determined. The ClO2-resistant population exhibited cross-resistance to free chlorine, but to none of the other inactivating treatments tested. We furthermore demonstrated that ClO2 and free chlorine act by a similar mechanism, in that they mainly inhibit the binding of echovirus 11 to its host cell. As such, viruses with host binding mechanisms that can withstand ClO2 treatment were also better able to withstand oxidation by free chlorine. Conversely, the UV-resistant population was not significantly cross-resistant to any other disinfection treatment. Overall, our results indicate that viruses with resistance to multiple disinfectants exist, but that they can be controlled by inactivating methods that operate by a distinctly different mechanism. We therefore suggest to utilize two disinfection barriers that act by different mechanisms in order to control disinfection-resistant viruses.
dc.subject: environmental virology||virus disinfection||echovirus 11||Cross-resistance||Water treatment
dc.title: Cross-resistance of UV- or chlorine dioxide-resistant echovirus 11 to other disinfectants
